text:
JOSH KRIEGER: Many of the
great advances in human health

have been due to
cutting edge drugs.

These innovations require not
only great scientific vision,

but a willingness to take on
great technical and commercial
uncertainty.

Generating the next
breakthrough therapies

depends on drug developers'
ability to identify and fund
high impact R&D.

While many organizations
want to pursue

these transformational projects,
risk aversion, career concerns,

and scientific norms often
steer firms towards more
incremental innovation.

And in collaboration with
Novartis' Genesis Labs program,

we've been studying the
evaluation of early stage
ideas.

How do scoring processes
influence the types of projects
that enter the pipeline?

We find that
scientist evaluators

show a bias for safer projects
even when the company looks
to be more daring.

We also find that evaluators are
quite sensitive to their peers
funding preferences.

If we want lifesaving
treatments in the clinic,

we have to learn how
to match the decisions

at the start of the R&D
pipeline to the therapies we

want for ourselves and
for our loved ones.
